title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "Department," and "infraction; violation." The Act defines key terms such as "Department" as the Department of State, "infraction; violation" as per Executive Order 13526, "Inspector General" for the Department of State and Broadcasting Board of Governors, "intelligence community" as defined in the National Security Act of 1947, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only state.gov email accounts, Department-owned telephonic systems, or other Department-managed electronic communications systems for work-related communication. Certification and reporting requirements apply. The Secretary must certify that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems and submit a report if certification cannot be made. The Secretary must report to Congress on Department employees lacking electronic communication access, reasons for the lack, steps taken to provide access, and ensure reliable work-related communication. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for electronic communication access for employees if certain conditions are met, including certification to congressional committees. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication access requirements for employees if certified to congressional committees that the waiver is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States and that all work-related written communications will be appropriately archived. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication access requirements for employees if certified to congressional committees that the waiver is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. Waivers issued are valid for up to 180 days and must be justified in writing to the appropriate committees. The Secretary may issue multiple waivers under paragraph (3) if consistent with certification and justification. The Inspector General must develop an oversight plan within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Inspector General must develop and implement an oversight plan to ensure compliance with the requirements of the Act by the Secretary and all Department employees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, that occurred in the previous fiscal year. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken in response. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken in response, including disciplinary actions, criminal referrals, and remedial training. If the employee had prior security violations in the last 10 years, and the Secretary did not terminate them, this must also be reported. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken in response, including disciplinary actions, criminal referrals, and remedial training. If the employee had prior security violations in the last 10 years and the Secretary did not terminate them, a justification must be provided. The report required under subsection (a) may not be made public and must be transmitted in a way that protects information under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials to receive training in detecting classified information spillage. Officials collect random samples of emails from Department employees with security clearances for Secret or higher information each quarter. The Inspector General audits the work of officials trained to detect classified information spillage and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The training includes rules and procedures for receiving, handling, and transmitting classified information. The curr_chunk discusses the appropriate handling of classified information, focusing on rules and procedures for electronic transmission, derivative classification, and safeguarding information when creating secondary documents or communications. The curr_chunk addresses the handling of foreign government information, processing requests under the Freedom of Information Act, and challenges to classification status. The curr_chunk discusses challenges to classification status, including the protection of classified information that has been disclosed without authorization. The curr_chunk highlights the importance of not automatically declassifying classified information due to unauthorized disclosure. It also emphasizes the Secretary's responsibility to demonstrate personal commitment and allocate resources for the effective implementation of programs for handling and protecting classified information. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need to commit resources for effective implementation of programs for handling and protecting classified information, ensuring agency records systems are optimized for sharing and safeguarding, designating a senior official to administer the program, and including classified information management in personnel evaluations. The curr_chunk highlights the importance of evaluating classified information in personnel performance reviews, outlining penalties for rule violations, and requiring employees to certify their understanding of training, rules, and responsibilities. Employees with security clearances at the Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information level must prioritize emergency refresher training. They must also certify their understanding of national security information access privileges and agree not to violate any rules or procedures under penalty of applicable laws. Employees with security clearances must undergo emergency refresher training in a specific order based on their clearance level. The Secretary has the authority to delay this training for up to 30 days for certain individuals or groups if it is deemed necessary for critical foreign policy interests. The Secretary can delay emergency refresher training for up to 30 days for individuals or groups if it is necessary for critical foreign policy interests, with notification to congressional committees. "Applicable rules and procedures" include relevant federal statutes and executive orders. The requirements for handling classified information include compliance with Executive Order 13526, current executive orders, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program within 180 days to educate Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems, in compliance with federal security standards. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days of the Act's enactment to complete reforms within one year. The plan includes developing a training program for Department employees to identify classified information. The program aims to train Department employees in identifying classified information under the Freedom of Information Act and ensuring intelligence community officials can make classification determinations. The intelligence community officials have the opportunity to determine the classification status of information. A training program is being developed for Department officials on archiving emails and electronic communications in compliance with relevant laws and regulations. The Department requires employees to annually swear that they have archived all documents, including emails, in accordance with specific laws and regulations. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation of the plan for appropriate archiving and securing of information within one year of the Act's enactment.
